This Risk Management Plan (RMP) was prepared for the purpose of demonstrating compliance with the requirements of Section 112? of the Clean Air Act pursuant to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) regulations contained in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR Part 68) Sections 68.1 ? 68.220, Accidental Release Prevention Provisions.

40 CFR Part 68 requires stationary sources with listed substances present in a quantity greater than the corresponding threshold quantity to develop and implement a Risk Management Program that includes a hazard assessment, a prevention program, a management system, and an emergency response program.  The Risk Management Program is to be described in an RMP that is registered with the USEPA, submitted to state and local agencies, and made available to the public.  At the Lee Hall facility, chlorine, which is a listed substance, is stored in a quantity greater than its threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds (lbs).

This RMP was prepared in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68, Subpart G, 68.150 ? 68.190.  In accordance with 40 CFR Part 68.10(d)(2), since accidental releases of chlorine have the potential to result in an offsite impact and chlorine storage operations are subject to the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, Program 3 requirements apply to this facility.

The Lee Hall facility uses chlorine in its water treatment process for disinfection and destruction of disease-producing organisms that may be present in the water.  Chlorine is stored at the Lee Hall facility as a liquid under pressure in one ton steel cylinders.  These cylinders are stored both inside and outside of a building.  The liquid chlorine is transferred from the cylinders to a chlorine evaporator.  Upon vaporization, the chlorine is then sent to the chlorinators which control the chlorine dosage to the specific applications.  The Lee Hall maximum intended inventory of chlorine is 20 cylinders.

The Lee Hall facility?s accid

ental release prevention and emergency response procedures are based on the goal of storing and handling this substance in a manner that presents exposure to employees and the nearby community.  It is the facility?s policy to adhere to applicable state and federal regulations.

The Lee Hall facility, as part of its accidental release prevention program, requires both current and newly hired operators and maintenance personnel to complete and pass the facility?s Personnel Qualification Standards (PQS).  The PQS consists of training in the following subjects: operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.  The Lee Hall facility also conducts equipment inspection and maintenance activities as part of the accidental release prevention program.

The Lee Hall facility has an existing emergency response plan that incorporates emergency response and coordination procedures for chlorine releases.  The local fire department and local emergency planning committee are included in this plan.

The Lee Hall facility conducted a process hazards analysis (PHA) in June 2004.  In addition, the facility is in the process of converting from chlorine to sodium hypochlorite. The conversion to sodium hypochlorite is expected to be completed during the first quarter of 2005.
